title: How to focus on my real life and stop focusing on my virtual life and gaming - Quora

response.answer_text: It seems you've already answered your question. However, your problem is really one of dopamine, and your sources for it. What do I mean? Well, in your virtual world, the only limits to your ability to succeed is in your ability to play the game and succeed in an algorithm. It is infinite potential, the only real currency for the reward is time. Life isn't so neat. One can pour in vast amounts of time and achieve little or nothing. So the reward in terms of satisfaction for achievement is clearly on the side of the game. What you need is a life hack to find satisfaction in real world outcomes that often seem very small to having a level 100 character in a virtual plane. The way to do this is to alter your thinking and your definition of satisfaction so that you get the same spike in dopamine from the incremental progress one makes in the real world. Set some goals. Make them meaningful and achievable. Then put forth your effort to achieve them. The real challenge with life is that it doesn't already have side quests laid out for you. You literally devise your own dungeon. There are no blocks to mine. There are also no rules for game play. This open-endedness makes getting started really hard for most people. Make it simple. Start by reading a book. Make it a fun one. I recommend Stranger In A Strange Land by Robert Heinlein. It's old. It's thick. It's thought provoking. And it's anything but elementary. Get through it. Then read another one. This is the kind of stuff you were trading in for your virtual achievements. Take up a musical instrument. Start painting. Do something which has no definition of success except for the one you place, and requires time to build skill. You won't have time for gaming and you'll have all the same dopamine satisfaction as before, but with real world skills exchanged for that time. Thanks for asking, I hope you succeed.

Change is hard, but possible. Start small: lets start with getting fit/health, as this will tie into having more energy during the day (maybe help with grades), friends (many fitness activities have social aspects/will cause you to meet people), etc. Find something you enjoy—this is really important. If you hate the activity, it is going to be really hard to maintain motivation. To get started, you could decide you are going to go for a 30 minute walk a couple times a week, and build from there. E.g., for me, I get bored with a lot of weight-lifting activities, and most sports aren’t very appealing to me, but I enjoy martial arts. My wife enjoys kettlebell exercises, but gets bored easily with a lot of other gym stuff. Do you like nature/outdoors? Walking, hiking, jogging, running. If you stick to the same areas you will meet people over time. Parkour, martial arts, running, weight lifting, body weight exercises, sports, hell even live action role playing can get you some exercise. Try a bunch of stuff out and find what you enjoy most (or dislike least) and try sticking with it a few months. The biggest thing though is overcoming the urge to stay as things are. The first step is hard, but it is to get up and go do something.

Hello Find a happy medium. It is ok for you to enjoy a virtual reality. But there needs to be balance. The fact that you posed this question means you are self aware, and recognize that this ‘addiction’ is holding you back? Take small steps. Choose one new thing to implement into your routine/schedule for a week. Reflect on the changes and how it made you feel. For instance, you could challenge yourself to go for a 30 minute walk every day for a week. Phone someone- anyone, your grandparents, an aunt, a cousin, and talk to them. Have a real conversation with a real person. Cook food. Challenge yourself to cook one new recipe every day for a week. Once you have done something new everyday, reflect on the week. Reflect on how you feel. Then try to implement more things, and for longer periods of time. And remember, it is ok to still have your love of virtual gaming/life! Just try to treat it more as a hobby :) Be Well.

Hi Niels! Thanks for asking for support. Your question shows great self-awareness; you can be proud of yourself for that. It’s human nature to gravitate toward things that are the most rewarding, and/or to gravitate away from situations that are distinctly unrewarding. And when I say it’s “human nature,” I mean the brain physically reinforces that tendency. Search on “reward center dopamine” if you want to learn more about that. You mention grades and parents - are they making you feel like you’re not good enough? If you’re feeling at all like a failure IRL, then it’s human nature to avoid those situations. And the online world offers so many ways to create feelings of success. Games do that especially: Every time you score a point, kill a boss, or reach a new level, the reward center in your brain gets another boost that makes you feel good. You know that rush you get when you achieve something in a game? That’s what I’m talking about. You DO have the power to make the change you’re looking for. The key is to create feelings of success IRL however you can. Start REALLY small, like “today I’m going to make my bed” or some easy thing like that. AND THEN DO IT. Every time you make a commitment and follow through on it, the reward center of your brain will get a boost and you’ll feel good. Start with one small thing today; tomorrow, commit to TWO small things and make sure you do them. Gradually add more things. At some point, since you mentioned better grades, start adding new goals that will help you get better grades. Maybe it’s clearing a place to do your homework, for example. Maybe it’s a goal of reading 1 chapter of a book. Maybe it’s “today I’m going to do all of my homework before I go online.” THE MOST IMPORTANT PART is that whatever you say you’re going to do, you get it done. The sense of completion & success is what triggers the reward center of your brain to help you feel good. You’ve got this, Niels. I have faith in you. In Loving Service, Christina <3

Firstly, congratulations for the realisation and the decision to change. That is the first step which will steer yourself into changing this aspect in your life, provided you have the determination to take it through. I do not have an idea of your personal circumstances but here are a few tips that might help you: Start small. Every day spend at least an hour (could be lesser) staying completely away from all gadgets which will tempt you into gaming or any such distraction. Slowly increase this time everyday Take a stock of the productivity you achieve when you are away from this habit. Spend time in an activity you love, this could be an outdoor/indoor sport, craft activity, music, reading, gardening or even just sitting idle and brooding. Spend time with nature everyday, even if it is for 10 minutes Practice mindfulness or meditation. They are plenty of resources online but I recommend a real life guru if this is possible. Take support of your loved ones, this could be family or close friends. Good luck!

First, I want to tell you how great I think your question is. They sat that acknowledging the problem is the first step to recovery. Start by getting at least 30 minutes of fresh air exercise a day. It is best if you can do this with a family member. Run, jog or walk. But get out, and start getting addicted to fresh air exercise. Next, eat meals as a family. This may sound silly, but families that eat meals together are happier and healthier. After that, join a school club (NOT THE GAMING CLUB!) Perhaps unified PE or Drama, where you give back a little at the same time. Or the math club, chess club- heck any club where you use your brain and not your mouse. Become a person of habit- good habits. make your bed every day- that may seem silly, but at the end of the day, you will see a well made bed, Make your bed, shower, wash your clothes, do things that need to be done, and you will find you have less time to wast hanging out online. FInd a passion. For me it flying- really- think about becoming a pilot, or anything that requires a great commitment- play golf, chess, something that requires you to get passionate. Good luck. Now get off Quora and go live life.

Begin by noticing when you spend your large blocks of internet time. My guess is between school and dinner, then again in the evening. Now think of some things you could do in the real world during those times. Start small. For example, offer to wash up after dinner. Once that becomes usual (and if you live in a safe neighborhood), see if your family will join you for a walk around the block after you wash up. Similarly, you could offer to pick up a few groceries after school on your way home, or volunteer for a short while at the local pet shelter or some such. Just keep nibbling into your internet time until you feel you have a good balance.

Find a balance of both. Nothing wrong with gaming but the main reason people love gaming nonstop is because the games removes the probability of scenarios that the person cannot control. As a result gaming gives a lot of control and removes real fears and the person gains a sense of fake control over things. Real life is much harder with many obstacles and challenges that a person cannot control easily but real development and growth occurs in the real world versus game simulation. Have realistic view that the real life will challenge you in ways the game can’t and determine if you are up for it.

The key to changing any behavior is to find something more important or more enjoyable. Your new activity could be social, physical or spiritual. For adults I recommend volunteering at a non-profit organization that is dealing with an issue that they care deeply about. Volunteering usually involves all three aspect--social, physical and spiritual. Your opportunities will be more limited for a few more years. Perhaps you can find a similar outlet for your energy.

Try to plan events with people you like during the time that you would regularly be playing video games. Sometimes events cost money, and if you’re only 15 you probably don’t have a good job yet so try to do things that are free or cheap. Bowling is cheap, look for free music shows, hang out in the park and toss around a ball for a while. Going outside and tossing the ball around seems like it’s lame but it’s actually really nice on a beautiful day.

Get a camera, not your smartphone, a real camera. Start taking walks and photograph the sights you see. Begin studying objects, subjects, scenes. Connect with the light and dark balance, color, and stories. Join a club or group that walks photoshots together. With a digital camera, a local drug store can develop photos in seconds, so your rewards are very instantaneous. Eventually you will find yourself putting your work on the internet, maybe even for money. Then try film!

Let me tell you it’s not easy. Not like pulling a Band-Aid. But cold turkey is the way to go for now. As far as I know there is no 12 step program but you could take a look at one and try to follow the steps, substituting words as needed. Isolation takes a while to get into and a while to get out of. It will take time for people to trust that you are really looking to be a part of the real world again. You may backslide. There are a lot of parallels between isolating yourself in a virtual world and addiction. You may have burned bridges, people may not trust you. It might take time to re-assimilate. It’s worth it. It will do you good in later life. It’s great that you are recognizing this as a problem now. Stick with it.

Decide what you think is a reasonable amount of time to spend online. An hour a day? Two hours? Fifteen minutes? Whatever the amount, write it down and look at it first thing in the morning. Then when you go online, set a timer. When the timer goes off, stop and go do something else. You might want to divide your time up into different short segments such as four periods of fifteen minutes instead of an hour straight. However you do it, stop when the timer goes off and go straight to something else. Hope this helps!

Don't go cold turkey on gaming. Continue gaming if you like it, BUT, everything has a limit. Make sure your gaming isn't hampering your studies or other things that you have to do. Spare some time of the day, like 1–2 hours for gaming and try not to game outside of that. You can also reward yourself with gaming, like if you finish 5 chapters, you get to play your favourite game for 30 minutes, something like this. If you really want to leave gaming, try reducing the amount you play slowly each day, even 5 minutes count. Get busy with other hobbies, suppose reading, for example. But again, if you really find joy in gaming, don't cut it out. Just make sure to keep things in control.
